name: PONG (Model 25796)
description: This is the Sears version of Atari Pong (model C-100). Read this entry for more info.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTERS IN THE EXAM ROOM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The major argument of the advert campaign was "we have a better and cheaper computer than Apple and IBM"...<br><br> True, but like many other computers of the time, the major fault of the Advantage was not to be an IBM system...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Right now, your computer for today"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SCARY...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Can you believe it?! She is learning how to play flute (mini flute?) with her TO7... The father seems to be a kind of lunatic...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Neurons' jogging"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode!  If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then.  Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics.  Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font>       </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computing today to be ready for tomorrow"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HOMO-COMPUTERUS</strong></font><br><blockquote>This image is from a brochure of a Dutch exhibition called "The office of the future"  <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of the <b>Computer museum of the University of Amsterdam</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A TO7 from Thomson fills the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID SITUATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>A translation would be : "the 10 years old and more children appreciate quickly the computing principles and have a lot of fun with their ZX-80" <br><br> So they say...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
